data.topic: Home Visitors, Field Agents & Public Services
data.overview: This scam happens when someone pretends to be from the police or CBI. They call you and say you are in big trouble, maybe linked to a crime. They then ask you for money to avoid being arrested or to clear your name.
important_tips: Never share your One Time Password (OTP) with anyone.
Always keep your personal documents like Aadhaar and PAN safe.
Carefully check any payment links before you click on them.
how_it_works: Scammers call or video call you, pretending to be from the police or CBI.
They say your name is linked to a serious crime, like a money issue or a suspicious parcel.
They might show you fake ID cards or made-up documents on the video call.
They then demand you send money to a 'safe' account to prove you are innocent or stop your arrest.
They often tell you to keep this whole matter a secret from everyone.
red_flags: Someone claiming to be police or CBI calls you unexpectedly and makes serious accusations.
They ask you to send money to 'fix' a legal problem or avoid going to jail.
They tell you not to tell anyone else about the call and to stay on the line.
They pressure you to act very quickly, making you feel scared or rushed.
They use video calls where people are in uniforms but the situation feels strange.
prevention_steps: Remember that real police or government offices never ask for money over the phone or a video call.
If someone calls claiming to be from the police, hang up and call the official police station directly to check.
Never share your bank details, OTP, or transfer money to anyone who pressures you like this.
If you feel uneasy or suspicious during a call, it's best to simply hang up.
Always confirm any serious claims by calling official numbers you find yourself, not numbers given by the caller.
real_world_examples: A person gets a call saying their Aadhaar card was used in a crime and they need to pay a 'fine' to clear it.
Someone receives a video call from a person in a fake police uniform demanding money to close a 'case' linked to their bank account.
A scammer tells an elderly person that a parcel with illegal items was sent in their name and they must pay immediately to avoid arrest.
what_to_do_if_you_are_a_victim: Do not panic, take a deep breath.
Stop all contact with the scammer right away.
Inform your bank immediately if you have shared any money or bank details.
Report the scam to the police or the cybercrime helpline.
Talk to a trusted family member or friend about what happened.
safe_checklist: Did they ask for money to 'fix' a police or legal matter? (It should be NO)
Did they pressure you to keep the call a secret from everyone? (It should be NO)
Did they make you feel scared or rushed to make a decision? (It should be NO)
legal_help_and_reporting: You can call the National Cybercrime Helpline at 1930 for help.
You can visit the official cybercrime portal at cybercrime.gov.in to report the incident.
You can also go to your nearest police station to file a complaint.
